BlackPoint.Cause: A condition (often fungal-associated) in wheat kernels where the embryo end becomes dark brown to black; favoured by high humidity, delayed harvest or harvest-moisture stress. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
BlackPoint.Symptoms: Dark brown to black discoloration at the embryo end of kernels; shrivelled or degraded grain quality; may reduce seed germination. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Precautions: Harvest promptly and avoid delays when grain moisture remains high.
Use well-drained and ventilated storage to avoid fungal colonisation. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Use disease-free seed and treat seed when needed.

Chemical: Seed treatments with appropriate fungicides when seed lots show black point infection. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
Organic: Ensure good field hygiene and avoid conditions of delayed harvest or heavy rain during maturity.

FusariumFootRot.Cause: Fungal disease complex often involving species of Fusarium (e.g., Fusarium graminearum) causing root, crown or foot rot in wheat, especially under continuous cropping, dry soil stress and residue-borne inoculum. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
FusariumFootRot.Symptoms: Dark brown lesions on stem base or sub-crown internode; plants stunted or prematurely dying; patches of weakened plants in field. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
Precautions: Rotate crops and avoid continuous wheat on same field.
Use well-drained soils and avoid drought or seedbed stress at emergence.
Use certified seed and consider fungicide seed treatment when risk is high.

Chemical: Use seed treatment fungicides designed for root/foot-rot pathogens.
Organic: Increase soil organic matter to improve root health and reduce stress-related susceptibility.

HealthyLeaf.Cause: No major disease or pest stress detected; wheat plants growing under favourable conditions.
HealthyLeaf.Symptoms: Green uniform leaves, no necrotic lesions or discolouration; good tillering and healthy grain set.
Precautions: Monitor regularly and keep field hygiene to avoid introducing pathogens.

Chemical: No treatment required â€” maintain preventive programmes.
Organic: Use compost or organic amendment to support soil health; maintain good crop rotation.

LeafBlight.Cause: Foliar diseases of wheat (often a complex including spot blotch, tan spot, other fungal pathogens) causing necrotic lesions on leaves under warm, humid conditions. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
LeafBlight.Symptoms: Elongated brown to dark brown blotches or spots on leaves; may cause premature leaf drop, reduced photosynthesis and yield loss.
Precautions: Ensure good plant spacing for air flow and reduce leaf wetness duration.
Rotate crops and remove crop residues to lower inoculum.

Chemical: Apply fungicides early when lower leaves show lesions and weather conditions favour spread.
Organic: Remove infected leaves, maintain strong plant health via fertilisation and avoid stress.

WheatBlast.Cause: Aggressive fungal disease caused by Magnaporthe oryzae Triticum pathotype (MoT) in wheat; spreads via infected seed, crop residue and airborne spores; favoured by warm, humid weather around flowering. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
WheatBlast.Symptoms: Bleached or shrivelled heads, dark lesions on spikes, grain shrivelling within a week of infection; rapid crop collapse in epidemic. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
Precautions: Use certified disease-free seed and avoid fields with history of blast.
Plant early to avoid peak conditions favourable for disease; monitor weather risk.
Rotate with non-wheat crops and avoid reservoir grasses or volunteer wheat.

Chemical: Chemical control is limited; fungicide applied at heading may reduce severity but is not wholly reliable.
Organic: Emphasise quarantine and removal of infected plants; adopt resistant varieties if available.
